review.title: Online Spatial Concept and Lexical Acquisition with Simultaneous Localization and Mapping
review.abstract: In this paper, we propose an online learning algorithm based on a Rao-Blackwellized particle filter for spatial concept acquisition and mapping. We have proposed a nonparametric Bayesian spatial concept acquisition model (SpCoA). We propose a novel method (SpCoSLAM) integrating SpCoA and FastSLAM in the theoretical framework of the Bayesian generative model. The proposed method can simultaneously learn place categories and lexicons while incrementally generating an environmental map. Furthermore, the proposed method has scene image features and a language model added to SpCoA. In the experiments, we tested online learning of spatial concepts and environmental maps in a novel environment of which the robot did not have a map. Then, we evaluated the results of online learning of spatial concepts and lexical acquisition. The experimental results demonstrated that the robot was able to more accurately learn the relationships between words and the place in the environmental map incrementally by using the proposed method.

sections.text: In this article, we present a novel model in which we can learn independently and apply spatial concepts and vocabularies to different places. However, spatial concepts are designed so that they can be learned autonomously on the basis of object concepts. Therefore, it is difficult to design spatial concepts in advance and it is desirable that the robots learn spatial concepts on the basis of their own experiences. Related research fields of semantic mapping and spatial categorization have aroused considerable interest in recent years. However, most of these studies consisted of separate independent methods of semantics of places and simultaneous localisation (SLAM) [3].

sections.heading: III. EXPERIMENTS
sections.text: We conducted experiments on online learning of spatial concepts from a novel environment. In addition, we performed evaluations of location categorization and location-based lexical capture. We compared the performance of four methods as follows: (A) SpCoSLAM (B) Online SpCoA based on RBPF (C) Online SpCoA (D) SpCoA (Batch Learning) [5] Methods (A), (B) and (C) conducted online learning algorithms based on CRP representation. Methods (B) and (C) did not update a language model. Method (D) conducted Gibbs sampling based on a weak threshold approximation [20] of the stick-breaking process (SBP) [21], i.e. the upper limit of spatial concepts and position distributions were defined as L = 100 or K = 100. In batch learning (D) we performed Gibbs sampling for Iterings.

sections.heading: A. Online learning
sections.text: We conducted experiments to capture spatial concepts online in a real-world environment. We expanded the gmapping package and implemented the grid-based FastSLAM 2.0 [9], [10] in the robot operating system (ROS). We used an open dataset (albert-b-laser-vision) that contained a Rosbag file that recorded odometry, laser range data and vision data. This dataset was extracted from the Robotics Data Set Repository (Radish) [22]. The authors thank Cyrill Stachniss for providing this data. We prepared a Japanese speech signal that corresponded to the movement of the robot of the above dataset because it did not contain speech signal data. There were 10 places and there were nine place names. The teaching expressions included 10 types of different phrases. The total number of expressions was 50. The microphone used was Julius Julius Julius GURG271, the language detection system.

sections.heading: IV. CONCLUSION
sections.text: The proposed method integrated the capture of spatial concepts in SLAM using an RBPF-based approach. In the experiments, we conducted online learning in a novel environment of the robot without an existing lexicon and a map. Experimental results showed that SpCoSLAM enhances the performance of location recognition using a speech signal in online learning methods. SpCoSLAM improved the over-segmentation problem in lexical capture by sequentially updating the language model. We believe that the inclusion of forgetting [14] and rejuvenation [26] in SpCoSLAM could further improve estimation accuracy. One of the advantages of online learning is that it can deal with changes in the environment and place names. Furthermore, we believe that the spatial concepts that the robot erroneously learns can also be corrected in spatial environments. In this way, it is possible to acquire spatial concepts that are flexible to work that we cannot expect to react to long-term spatial changes in the environment and to each other.
